clinical_study.brief_title: A Comprehensive Smoking Cessation Intervention Duration Radiation for Upper Aerodigestive Cancers
clinical_study.official_title: Efficacy and Impact of a Comprehensive Smoking Cessation Intervention During Radiation for Upper Aerodigestive Cancers

lead_sponsor.agency: Sidney Kimmel Comprehensive Cancer Center at Johns Hopkins

collaborator.agency: National Institute of Dental and Craniofacial Research (NIDCR)

clinical_study.source: Sidney Kimmel Comprehensive Cancer Center at Johns Hopkins

brief_summary.textblock: Smoking is the greatest risk factor for upper aerodigestive cancers (thoracic or head and neck) and negatively impacts survival and other outcomes, but many patients have difficulty quitting after their diagnosis. Smoking cessation interventions for cancer patients thus far have had limited success. This is a pilot randomized controlled trial designed to determine if a new comprehensive, evidence-based smoking cessation intervention can improve quit rates for cancer patients who smoke.

primary_outcome.description: Smoking cessation will be defined as BOTH (1) self-reported 7-day abstinence from smoking and (2) exhaled carbon monoxide level of 8 or lower as biochemical confirmation of abstinence.

arm_group.description: New evidence-based comprehensive smoking cessation intervention including several elements that have proven successful in non-cancer patients but not used for cancer patients before.
Intervention consistent with the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services guidelines for tobacco treatment.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- New diagnosis of head and neck or thoracic (including lung) cancer
- Undergoing radiation at Johns Hopkins Radiation Oncology for 5 or more weeks
- English-speaking and able to provide informed consent
- Smoked any cigarettes in previous 14 days
Exclusion Criteria:
- Palliative radiation
- Undergoing stereotactic radiosurgery
- Pregnant or breastfeeding
